column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

The supply of cattle fell by 580 for a yarding 1870 head. Quality was mostly good throughout, with a similar number of prime cattle to last sale, however store pens consisted of many smaller lines. Only three regular processors were in attendance and operating, supported by one live exporter, regular feeders and opportunity retsockers.  Cattle were drawn from Burketown, Richmond, Greenvale, Harveyâ€™s Range, local and coastal areas.

Reduced demand for prime cattle saw values ease with bullocks down 10-18c, cows 3 to 12c lower and heavy bulls averaged 10-20c less.

Young suitably weaned steers to backgrounders averaged 253c, selling to 282c. Similar heifers to processors made to 174c to average 170c/kg. Light yearling steers returning to the paddock made to 268c, averaging from 232c to 252c, steers above 280kg sold to 262c to average 246c/kg. Yearling heifers were insufficient to reliable quote and sold according to quality.

Grown steers above 400kg to the trade sold to 225c to average 214c, heavy grown steers reached 228c to average 221c/kg.  A good supply of grown heifers to the trade sold to 228c to average from 203c to 221c/kg.

A mixed quality sample of heavy full mouthed bullocks to export slaughter topped at 233c to average from 213c to 227c/ kg.  A large sample of medium weight 3 score cows to processors sold to 202c to average from 172c to 188c and a small number of prime heavyweight cows averaged 195c/kg.

Medium weight bulls to live export sold from 236c to 244c, heavy bulls to feed destined for live export sold to 246c multiple times to average 241c and processor bulls averaged 196c/kg.

Several good quality small lines of cows and calves sold from $1,000 to $1,240 per unit.

Market Reporter, Mick Kingham
